resource.chars:
Standing before the universal
symbol of the holiday season, the
brick fire-place with its Yuletide
logs, Katherine Baker accompanied
by Grace Warner at the piano, sang
a solo which opened the annual
Christmas entertainment presented
by the two Christian Associations
in the auditorium prior to the close
of school for the holidays.
When the drawn curtain opened
again, it was for the one act play,
The Christmas Burglar. Meg and
the Professor wmre busy trimming
the Christmas tree and all could not
have been happier had not Meg's
father been in jail. Then the absent
minded Professor has to go to the
store, and Dad comes in, and lastly
Skin comes upon the scene, much
to the complication and embarrass-
ment of everything and everybody.
Justice finally is meeted to the
burglar and all are happy. Hazel
Watson, as Meg, was delightful al-
though no less praise is due the
other members of the cast; B. H.
Powell, as the Professor, Ross
Smith, as Dad, and Duncan Clark,
as Skin.
Other numbers on the program
were:
Violin solo, Delma Bock.
Processional—“Hark! The Herald
Angels Sing.’’
Christmas Story, (Luke, 2)

Homer Washburn.
Hymn—O, Come All Ye Faithful!
Cundel Service.
Recitation—O. Little Town of
Bethlehem, Eva Atkinson.
Hymn—Holy Night.
Recitation—Keeping Christmas,
Betty Amos.
Hymn—The First Noel.
Exuent—-Joy to the World.
Those who were in the proces-
sional and took part in the candel
service, lead by Grace Warner and
Clark Seibert, were Julia Behring,
Katherine Baker, Priscilla Pancost,
Olive Wallis, Margaret Wolf, Anne
Hoffman, Anne Mathews, Bernice
Moler, Winifred McMinimy; Frank
Witter, Harold Seibert, Arthur
Hamilton, Lionel Newcomer, Frank
Terhune, Joe Endslow, Charles
Remsberg.
